notes:
1. Concept

Power screws (like square threads) are used to transmit power or motion. The mechanics are analyzed by "unwrapping" the thread into an inclined plane.

2. Key Parameters

  • Lead ($L$): Distance the screw advances in one revolution ($L = np$, where $n$ is number of starts, $p$ is pitch).
  • Mean Radius ($r_m$): Average radius of the thread.
  • Lead Angle ($\lambda$): $\tan \lambda = L / (2\pi r_m)$.
  • Friction Angle ($\phi$): $\tan \phi = \mu$.

3. Torque Equations

  • Torque to Raise Load ($T_R$): (Motion against load direction) $$ T_R = W r_m \tan(\phi + \lambda) $$
  • Torque to Lower Load ($T_L$): (Motion with load direction) $$ T_L = W r_m \tan(\phi - \lambda) $$

4. Self-Locking

A screw is self-locking if it stays in place under load without external torque. This occurs if the friction angle is greater than or equal to the lead angle ($\phi \ge \lambda$). If $\phi < \lambda$, the screw will overhaul (unwind) under the load.

solvedExamples.question: A power screw is self-locking if:

options.text: The lead angle is greater than the friction angle.
The friction angle is greater than the lead angle.

solvedExamples.explanation: Self-locking means friction is sufficient to prevent the load from causing the screw to turn backwards. Mathematically, this requires $\tan \phi \ge \tan \lambda$, or $\phi \ge \lambda$.

solvedExamples.question: If the torque required to lower a load is calculated to be negative, what does this imply?

options.text: The screw is not self-locking (it will overhaul).

solvedExamples.explanation: A negative lowering torque means you must apply torque *against* the direction of lowering to prevent the load from accelerating downwards. The load turns the screw by itself; this is the definition of overhauling.
